segments.text: Magnus Carlsen calls this chess opening for white, moving the queen out all the way here on your second turn, the best chess opening for beginners.
Even though it violates an important piece of advice often given to beginners.
Why is this?
Well, the way the game started so far is it started with very common opening moves, king's pawn for white, push two spaces forward, and similar for black.
This is the most common way to open a game of chess at the highest levels even as well.
And here, we then did something more unorthodox in moving our queen out.
And this violates the common opening principle for beginners, which is be careful about moving your queen out too early, because it can get attacked.
You'll have to waste time moving it around, or you might lose it.
And it's your most valuable piece.
You don't want to lose it.
But we've done it anyway for the sake of this opening.
Why is that?
It's an opening where you can get some very quick, cheap victories if you're playing against other chess beginners.
So for example, here we are attacking this pawn.
And so something that black might do is it might move this pawn here, which both
gets in the way of our attack and also attacks our queen.
But this is a really bad move for black because it leaves this pawn here undefended.
So we're just going to swoop in, take that, it's check because we're attacking the king, but also at the same time we're attacking this rook that is now open.
And so black must block and we just win the rook.
And this happens regardless of whether black might also try to block with bishop or block with knight.
Both of those mean we can still capture that rook.
So basically...
Pushing this pawn here, big mistake for black because of this pawn that's unguarded.
Check, and then a threat to the rook.
So instead, a better move for black might be developing a knight.
It's now protecting that pawn, so we can't capture it because otherwise the knight will recapture us.
So what should we do now?
This is actually our main plan anyway.
It's moving this bishop out here.
Why is this our main plan?
Well, it's because for a move like this here, blacks may be trying to attack our queen by developing their second knight.

Unfortunately, what this misses is when we moved our bishop, we meant we had two pieces now attacking that pawn, which means the queen can take it, attack the king, and also it's checkmate because the queen is guarded by the bishop and the king has nowhere to go.
And so that is a way that you can commonly win quickly from here if you're playing beginners in chess.
Lots of moves don't prevent that threat.
So anything that leaves those lines open to this pawn that might be, for example, moving this bishop here, still got checkmate.
Or if not moving that bishop here, maybe this pawn and moving that forward one space still leaves a line open to take.
and have checkmate.
So lots of ways that black can air here and leave them open for a quick checkmate.
Now, something that they can actually do is they can actually push this pawn forward here.
They couldn't earlier, because we saw that left this pawn open, the queen would swoop in, and we have a check, and we won the rook.
But here now, what's different is the blacks got this knight out.
And so this move here,
both stops our queen from coming in, attacks our queen, and we can't capture this pawn because the knight's there.
So maybe let's just move our queen around.
And now black might think, great, we've survived the danger.
Let's move the bishop out to develop.
What this misses is that from this new position, the queen is still attacking that pawn.
And so we can swoop in.
And again, it is checkmate.
And so this is an opening that gives you a few different ways to either checkmate or gain a huge advantage just within a few moves if your opponent doesn't know what they're doing.
